column4: is there an easy way to view the contents of an installed package from the CLI?
how is that different from dpkg -c package?
the man pages for apt aren't very descriptive
yeah...pkg mgmt in general - i'm really missing RPM at this point
i've spent most of the past day or so trying to figure out how to see what packages are installed and which aren't, etc
I think, from dpkg(1), that "-L, --listfiles package-name...  List files installed to your system from package-name" is fairly descriptive.
as oppose to "list contents of a deb package"
yes.  Feel free to file a bug and attach a patch to rectify the purported ambiguity.
at this point, i'm pretty frustrated with the whole apt system...sorry for whining
I presume you've discovered by now that `dpkg -l` will return which binary packages are installed?
i think so...i'm starting to think that dpkg is the correct way to interact with the apt db, rather than apt-cache
depends on the goal, I think.  apt-cache exposes "meta", like dependencies and such between packages (handled by dpkg).
an analogy could be yum vice rpm.
dpkg -l is a lot better than what i was doing...i was doing apt-cache pkgnames
